meeting_annotations.speaker: Erika Matunis JHMI
meeting_annotations.transcript: pros and cons.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Anna Marie Sokac, UIUC
meeting_annotations.transcript: I guess just to pick up on the idea we've kind of been talking a lot about metrics but dancing around another issue which is what do we actually value? What do we actually value, what is a good scientist? And I kind of think that this has to change if we're going to change the face of science. We need to grow a bigger appreciation for different kinds of skill sets and what different kinds of people can bring that's not, first of all, may not be credentialed in the way that we're used to, and it may mean that we have to think harder about what skills can really push our science forward. Do you always have to be a leader to push science forward?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Stephen Fried (he/him/JHU)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Mhm.
meeting_annotations.other: This is a brief backchannel affirmation.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Anna Marie Sokac, UIUC
meeting_annotations.transcript: I kind of think I just think about metrics and tied to that though are what are our values? And I'm really concerned about this actually when thinking about how to diversify our faculty because of course all these conversations are happening but I don't hear, I don't often hear people saying, well I'm willing to change or adapt my expectations in order to bring people on board. And that really concerns me.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Stephen Fried (he/him/JHU)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah. Actually related to that point. So Karen Fleming in our biophysics department here has been, we're piloting a sort of a hiring I guess strategy that I think was developed by one of the departments at Yale, maybe Caitlyn knows, I don't know who, but where the first round of the process will be anonymous where basically the candidates will have to prepare statements about their prior research experience, their future plans, their teaching statement, etcetera in a way that sort of would not reveal who they've worked for and sort of create this implicit bias of essentially without us saying it out loud we tend to hire people from the same few institutes and the same few labs within those institutes and so I'm really excited to see what happens with it.
meeting_annotations.other: He clasps his hands in front of his face, showing deep thought.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Lydia Kisley - CWRU
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah I was at a conference last week

meeting_annotations.speaker: Anna Marie Sokac, UIUC
meeting_annotations.transcript: Go ahead.
meeting_annotations.other: This is a turn-yielding statement to encourage Lydia to continue.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Lydia Kisley - CWRU
meeting_annotations.transcript: Oh go ahead.
meeting_annotations.other: Mutual turn-yielding, a moment of polite confusion over who should speak.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Nathan DeYonker (Memphis)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Thanks. So when I teach freshman chemistry I have this writing assignment early on where I ask them to flip through the textbook for five minutes and think about representation in the textbook and when the students write about whether or not they could find any human beings because maybe in five minutes if they have a slow internet connection and they're looking through the ebook they don't find somebody doing chemistry in their general chemistry textbook but a lot of them sometimes they find like Dmitri Mendeleev or Marie Curie and some of them say, I'll never be, I don't want to be a famous chemist or I'll never be a famous chemist and these intro textbooks they don't tell you that you can be a professional and you can be a leader without being a pioneer. And so there's this gatekeeping in intro science that's really I think unfortunate but maybe that's kind of on a younger level than what we're trying to discuss in this breakout room but how do we tell them that they can be scientists without needing to be extraordinary if they don't want to or need to.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erika Matunis JHMI
meeting_annotations.transcript: Lydia did you want to follow up on that?
meeting_annotations.other: She facilitates the conversation by directing the turn back to someone who was previously interrupted.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Lydia Kisley - CWRU
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah it was going to comment on some of the hiring stuff and I think I can bring in Nathan's comment as well that I was at a conference last week that was faculty and some postdocs getting ready for the job market and this was a point of discussion that can we recognize that great science can be done in many places and you don't just need to be coming from a top 10, have an experience at a top 10 institution because all the faculty there that talked about their last hires in the past five years they were all like yeah everybody was from these set institutions and that's limiting the ideas too because those are people that are only exposed to set groups and set things. So I think looping in Nathan's comment that not just a historical leader but like these easy metrics of groups and universities you can also make an impact and be a good scientist and have creative ideas even if you aren't coming from those places.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Grace Stokes (Santa Clara U)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Can I also kind of comment on that? Related to even like applying for grants or listing reviewers on papers and things like that. A lot of people I feel like will list people that they knew from graduate school or if you went to Berkeley then all of your people who you went to graduate school at Berkeley are now professors somewhere in the country or I feel like there's some kind of a buddy buddy system where if you didn't go to one of those top 10 institutions and you can't name drop people that you know at all the other institutions there's I don't know that that's a problem and then it feels like people who aren't in that upper echelon aren't part of the, don't have an edge in being able to get through the tenure process and getting started in their lab. I think they work harder and it's it's something that kind of has always bothered me a little bit that it seems like there's inequities yeah.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Grace Stokes (Santa Clara U)
meeting_annotations.transcript: But I wonder if things like where you can have a in-person conference and meet people through some of these things where you don't have to be already know everybody at a conference to be able to make connections and I don't know I'm still kind of torn about the whole Zoom versus in person but certainly Zoom seems to be a more convenient way for people to be able to meet people across the country.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Martin Gruebele
meeting_annotations.transcript: I will say that the Scialog is one of the rare exceptions in that it is a meeting where people who don't know each other get a chance to meet. I wish there were more of them. Which is why all of the, you saw all the senior people basically, hey I don't care if you do an astrophysics one I don't know any astrophysics but I'm just I'll go to it. There's a good reason for that.
meeting_annotations.other: He smiles and raises his hand in a friendly gesture.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erika Matunis JHMI
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah having an aspect to the culture like Rigoberto mentioned in his talk where people just set aside time and talk about maybe far out ideas, that's so important and it normally does happen at conferences when we used to go in person. It's definitely great to have it happen here but it doesn't need to necessarily happen in our university environments so maybe we can all be catalysts for change in that arena. You can say hey I would like one of my faculty meetings a month to be a brainstorm session right?
meeting_annotations.other: She smiles and laughs at the end, showing enthusiasm for the idea.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Stephen Fried (he/him/JHU)
meeting_annotations.transcript: I'm wondering if we could talk about grad students and mental health and faculty student relations. The only reason why I bring it up is because I kind of recently found out through some of the grad students who TA for me like some of the way my senior colleagues treat their grad students and it's really horrifying. And I just wish there was more QC in the culture.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erika Matunis JHMI
meeting_annotations.transcript: Well that should go right to your department chair. And if they don't help because they are one of the perpetrators you should go right to the dean. I mean there's always protection in systems for that.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Stephen Fried (he/him/JHU)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Well like nothing that the official institutions would care about but just sort of like overworking and

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erika Matunis JHMI
meeting_annotations.transcript: No no but I feel like the standards have totally changed and this is kind of related to our third point which is mentoring right? What was okay in mentoring five years ago is not okay now at all and it's just there are a few people who are still getting the message but this is a super important point.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Martin Gruebele
meeting_annotations.transcript: Let me follow up on what Stephen just said because so I'll make the argument that we actually have gone downhill not doing better but actually doing worse despite all of this awareness. And part of it has to do with the way we exploit young people just from the amount of time that we get out of them to do things. So to give you an example my advisor got his PhD at age 23 and had a faculty job at Berkeley with three publications at age 27. And I got mine at age 24 and had a faculty job at Illinois at age 28. And my students are getting their PhDs at age 29 and if they're lucky if they're done with their postdoc at 35 and getting a faculty job. And I don't think it's because my advisor was a hyper genius and I'm a genius and my students are morons. They're the same people.
meeting_annotations.other: He uses a hand gesture to illustrate a timeline/hierarchy.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erika Matunis JHMI
meeting_annotations.transcript: They're even better people.
meeting_annotations.other: This is a supportive and humorous interjection.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Martin Gruebele
meeting_annotations.transcript: But our system actually is built now in a way that encourages exploitation. And I'll give you just one example I don't know, I'll give you an example I think of how one might solve this although I have no idea whether that would actually work or not but one thing that's really different from the 1970s and early 80s and now is that in the 1970s the power of funding was in students' hands.
